title: 103_s2014
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States-Flag Passenger Vessel Act of 1994" and amends Section 8 of the Act of June 19, 1886 regarding coastwise transportation of passengers. The United States-Flag Passenger Vessel Act of 1994 amends regulations for coastwise transportation of passengers, specifying requirements for vessels and penalties for violations. Vessels must meet specific criteria and have proper documentation for coastwise trade. Violators face civil penalties and potential seizure of the vessel. The United States-Flag Passenger Vessel Act of 1994 regulates coastwise transportation of passengers, defining coastwise trade and passenger criteria. Travel agents promoting future trips on a voyage are not considered passengers under the Act. The United States-Flag Passenger Vessel Act of 1994 regulates coastwise transportation of passengers, defining coastwise trade and passenger criteria. An exception allows ineligible vessels to transport passengers in coastwise trade if they met certain conditions between 1990 and 1993 and file an affidavit with the Secretary of Transportation. The exception under the United States-Flag Passenger Vessel Act of 1994 allows ineligible vessels to transport passengers in coastwise trade under specific conditions, including compliance with listing trade routes. The exception expires after 15 years from vessel construction or major conversion, or 5 years after enactment if the vessel fails to meet crewing requirements. The exception under the United States-Flag Passenger Vessel Act of 1994 allows ineligible vessels to transport passengers in coastwise trade under specific conditions, including crewing requirements. After 5 years from enactment, vessels must have a crew of U.S. citizens or lawful residents, with no more than 25% being aliens with permanent residence. The exception ends when an eligible vessel enters service on the same trade route. To qualify for the exception under the United States-Flag Passenger Vessel Act of 1994, an eligible vessel must have a passenger capacity of at least 75% of the ineligible vessel's capacity. The owner or charterer of the eligible vessel must submit a notice of intent and evidence of offering the service to the Secretary of Transportation 270 days before entry into service. The United States-Flag Passenger Vessel Act of 1994 sets criteria for eligible vessels, including passenger capacity requirements and employment restrictions for non-U.S. citizens. The exception does not apply to ineligible vessels after a certain period or upon sale. The United States-Flag Passenger Vessel Act of 1994 defines eligible and ineligible vessels based on criteria such as passenger capacity and employment restrictions. An ineligible vessel is one that does not meet the requirements for a certificate of documentation for coastwise trade.
